Crime and Punishment

“Here he is! Dmitri Prokofitch Razumihin,” she said, introducing him to Luzhin. 

“I had the pleasure… yesterday,” Pyotr Petrovitch muttered, shooting a hostile glance at Razumihin. Then he scowled and went silent.

Pyotr Petrovitch was one of those people who act super polite in social settings. They care a lot about manners, but the second something doesn’t go their way, they turn into awkward messes—like sacks of flour instead of charming folks. 

Silence fell again. Raskolnikov stayed quiet, Avdotya Romanovna (Dounia) didn’t want to jump into the conversation too soon, and Razumihin had nothing to add. Pulcheria Alexandrovna was getting anxious again.

“Have you heard? Marfa Petrovna is dead,” she said, bringing up her go-to topic.

“Yes, I heard. I was told right away. I also found out that Arkady Ivanovitch Svidrigaïlov rushed to Petersburg right after his wife’s funeral. I have good sources on that,” he replied.

“To Petersburg? Here?” Dounia asked, alarmed, glancing at her mother.

“Yes, and he probably has some plan, considering how quickly he left and everything that happened before.”

“Good heavens! Will he leave Dounia alone even here?” Pulcheria Alexandrovna exclaimed. 

“I doubt either of you or Avdotya Romanovna…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Pyotr Petrovitch's polite demeanor masks his discomfort and hostility towards Razumihin as they discuss the recent death of Marfa Petrovna and the arrival of Svidrigaïlov in Petersburg.
